title: A Similarity Paradigm Through Textual Regularization Without Forgetting
author: Fangming Cui (Shanghai Jiao Tong University), Jan Fong (Hong Kong Baptist University), Rongfei Zeng (Northeastern University), Xinmei Tian (University of Science and Technology of China), Jun Yu (Harbin Institute of Technology (Shenzhen))
relevance_why: This paper proposes a method that utilizes optimal transport and a similarity paradigm to enhance generalization in visual-language models, which could inspire similar approaches in audio-related tasks where multi-modal learning is also applicable.
background: This research aims to improve the generalization capabilities of visual-language models by incorporating techniques that prevent forgetting essential knowledge and enhance robustness across various tasks.
contribution: The paper introduces the Similarity Paradigm with Textual Regularization (SPTR) to solve the issue of overfitting in prompt learning, achieving improved performance on generalization tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous prompting methods tend to overfit specific data distributions, leading to poor performance on unseen classes.
technical_comparison.novelty: SPTR combines optimal transport for textual regularization and similarity scoring to maintain generalization capabilities while tuning prompts.

key_innovation: The unique integration of optimal transport as a textual regularization method allows for fine-grained distance measurement between multiple text prompt distributions.
real_world_impact: By effectively improving the generalization of visual-language models, this research could inform advancements in related areas such as audio-visual learning, leading to more adaptable AI systems in real-world applications.

new_terms.optimal transport: **Optimal transport** refers to a mathematical theory for measuring the distance between two probability distributions and can be used to reallocate resources efficiently.
new_terms.similarity paradigm: **Similarity paradigm** is a conceptual framework used to compare and align data distributions to improve model robustness across variations.
